description: From Latin intēnsiō (“straining, effort; intensifying”), from intēnsus (“stretched”), perfect passive participle of intendō (“strain or stretch toward”) .

entries.meaning: intensity or the act of becoming intense .
(logic, semantics) Any property or quality connoted by a word, phrase or other symbol, contrasted with actual instances in the real world to which the term applies.
examples: This law is, that the intension of our knowledge is in the inverse ratio of its extension.

entries.meaning: (dated) A straining, stretching, or bending; the state of being strained.
examples: the intension of a musical string
